coredata.dc:title: Tungsten induced defects control on BiVO4 photoanodes for enhanced solar water splitting performance and photocorrosion resistance
coredata.dc:creator: Liu, Shujie
Gao, Rui-Ting

Wang, Zhaowu
Liu, Xianhu
Nakajima, Tomohiko

Su, Yiguo
Wang, Lei
coredata.dc:description: The stabilization of semiconductor against photocorrosion has become one of the most essential targets in photoelectrochemical water splitting. Herein, a research of three mixing enhancement strategies of WO3/BiVO4 heterojunction, W doping, and oxygen vacancy formation can be made to incorporate into such a nanostructure during the preparation of BiVO4 in terms of PEC performance improvement. The WO3 layer not only facilitated the electron transfer, but importantly, was used as a diffusion source for W doping which brought oxygen vacancies on the bulk material. Moreover, the introduction of different W doping profiles,- bottom, middle, and top, all electrodes exhibited a photo-activation character with the improved photocurrent and the negative shift of onset potential. The bottom W doping led to the most notable enhancement in charge separation efficiency on BiVO4 electrode, which yielded the close photocurrent densities of ∼4.4 mA cm−2 at 1.23 VRHE under front and back 1 sun illumination. More importantly, the cocatalyst-free W:BiVO4-Ov photoanode present a favorable stability during 25 h test applied at 1.0 VRHE. By experimental and theoretical arguments, it demonstrated that the multiple collaborative strategies shed light on designing efficient and stable photoelectrodes for solar energy conversion.

The DFT calculation was carried out at LvLiang Cloud Computing Center of China, and it was performed on TianHe-2.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a-c) LSV curves for top W:BVO (a), middle W:BVO (b), and bottom W:BVO (c) in 1 M KBi under AM 1.5 G front and back illumination; (d) J-t curves for the corresponding photoanodes applied at 0.8 VRHE in 1 M KBi under AM 1.5 G front illumination; (e) LSV curves for top W:BVO-Ov, middle W:BVO-Ov, and bottom:BVO-Ov after photo-activation in 1 M KBi under AM 1.5 G front illumination; (f) LSV curves for bottom W:BVO-Ov after photoactivation in 1 M KBi under AM 1.5 G front and back illumination; (g) comparison of photocurrents on electrodes at 1.23 VRHE before and after photo-activation; (h) UV–vis spectra for top W:BVO-Ov, middle W:BVO-Ov, and bottom W:BVO-Ov; (i) J-t curves for corresponding electrodes applied at 1.0 VRHE under AM 1.5 G front illumination. The J-t curve of BVO was shown for comparison.

(a) SEM and (b) FIB-STEM images of W:BVO; (c) XRD patterns of WO3, BVO, bottom W:BVO (W:BVO), and bottom W:BVO-Ov; (d) cross-sectional STEM image and (e-i) elemental mappings of W:BVO; (j) TEM image of W:BVO-Ov. Inset shows low magnification image; (k) UPS spectra of WO3, W:BVO, and W:BVO-Ov; (l) indirect and (m) direct bandgaps of WO3, W:BVO, and W:BVO-Ov; (n) band diagrams of corresponding electrodes.

(a-e) XPS spectra of W:BVO-Ov polarized potentiostatically at 0.8 VRHE for various times (0, 100 s, 1 h, and 6 h): (a) Bi 4f, (b) V 2p, (c) O 1s, and (d) W 4f; (e) XPS W 4f spectrum of WO3 grown on FTO; (f) EPR spectra of W:BVO-Ov after potentiostatic polarization for various times.

Electrochemical characterization of BVO, W:BVO, and W:BVO-Ov: (a) IPCE spectra; (b) EIS curves. Inset shows the equivalent circuit model; (c) Mott-Schottky plots; (d) surface separation efficiency; (e) bulk charge-separation efficiency; (f) photocurrent transient behaviors applied at 0.8 VRHE; (g) time-resolved photoluminescence (TRPL) emission spectra; (h) room temperature photoluminescence (PL) spectra. The electrodes were excited at 525 nm; (i) absorbance spectra.

(a-d) Density of states of (a) pristine BVO, (b) W:BVO, (c) W:BVO with one oxygen vacancy (W:BVO-Ov), and (d) W:BVO with two oxygen vacancies (W:BVO-Ov'). (e,f) Gibbs free-energy diagrams of OER on (e) BVO and (f) W:BVO-Ov.

head.ce:title: Tungsten induced defects control on BiVO4 photoanodes for enhanced solar water splitting performance and photocorrosion resistance

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The stabilization of semiconductor against photocorrosion has become one of the most essential targets in photoelectrochemical water splitting. Herein, a research of three mixing enhancement strategies of WO3/BiVO4 heterojunction, W doping, and oxygen vacancy formation can be made to incorporate into such a nanostructure during the preparation of BiVO4 in terms of PEC performance improvement. The WO3 layer not only facilitated the electron transfer, but importantly, was used as a diffusion source for W doping which brought oxygen vacancies on the bulk material. Moreover, the introduction of different W doping profiles,- bottom, middle, and top, all electrodes exhibited a photo-activation character with the improved photocurrent and the negative shift of onset potential. The bottom W doping led to the most notable enhancement in charge separation efficiency on BiVO4 electrode, which yielded the close photocurrent densities of ∼4.4 mA cm−2 at 1.23 VRHE under front and back 1 sun illumination. More importantly, the cocatalyst-free W:BiVO4-Ov photoanode present a favorable stability during 25 h test applied at 1.0 VRHE. By experimental and theoretical arguments, it demonstrated that the multiple collaborative strategies shed light on designing efficient and stable photoelectrodes for solar energy conversion.

ce:section.ce:para: The utilization of photoelectrochemical (PEC) electrolysis of water has recently attracted considerable attention for clean energy hydrogen [1–6]. Bismuth vanadate (BiVO4) with a suitable band gap and band edge position becomes one of the most promising candidates for PEC hydrogen production [7,8]. However, the low carrier mobility and short carrier diffusion length result in the high photogenerated carrier recombination rate, which severely restricts its photocurrent density up to the theoretical value of 7.5 mA cm−2 and sloar-to-hydrogen (STH) conversion efficiency lower than that of 9.2 % [9–11]. Importantly, it suffers from the photocorrosion during long-term PEC measurement. To address these issues, various strategies including synthesis method, [12–14] element doping, [15–17] heterojunction structure, [18–23] and cocatalysts deposition [24–27] have been employed for improving the charge transfer rate and reducing the carrier recombination.

On the other hand, most of PEC performances on BiVO4 photoanodes are obtained from the back solar illumination which is caused by the poor electron transport properties. The vast majority strategies could not ameliorate the situation for facilitating the electron transfer, and the BiVO4 photoanodes still need to be illuminated from the back side. The front-illuminated PEC performance is therefore lower than that of the back illumination. Further on, regarding constructing a practical tandem-electrode application or a non-biased PEC water splitting system, excellent front-illuminated performance is essential for potentially large-scale hydrogen production, in which sunlight principally comes from the front side of photoelectrode [12,28]. Recent studies have shown that the charge transfer rate of BiVO4 can be significantly improved by coupling with metal oxide (MOx) semiconductors underneath the BiVO4 samples (e.g. WO3, SnO2, and ZnO) without a remarkable reduction of light absorption [29–33]. These layers have been supposed to be an electron transfer layer thanks to the facilitated band position between BiVO4 and MOx [34]. For instance, Jang et al. reported that a heterojunction photoanode composed of nanoporous BiVO4 and SnO2 nanorods, exhibited an improved charge separation efficiency of 97 % and a high photocurrent of 5.61 mA cm−2 at 1.23 VRHE with a loading of NiFe cocatalyst in potassium borate electrolyte under front-side 1 sun illumination [28]. The rational design of photoanodes with the band structures is critical to obtain the high front-illuminated PEC performances. However, without further co-catalyst modification or employing a hole scavenger, the photocurrent densities of the BiVO4-based photoanodes are still unsatisfactory. Additionally, most of researches on the heterojunction structures selected the neutral electrolyte (e.g. Na2SO4) during the experiment, which would weaken the PEC performances of BiVO4 to some extent. In view of these, it is necessary to exploit an alternative strategy that can complement the previously reported approach, to enhance front-illuminated photocurrent of BiVO4 photoanode for further advance practical application.

Hence, in this work a new strategy was designed to prepare WO3 modified BiVO4 photoanode with defects control. The WO3 layer not only facilitated the electron transfer, but more importantly, was used as a W doping source which brought oxygen vacancies on the bulk material. Further, different W doping profiles - top, middle, and bottom, were induced, and all electrodes presented a photo-activation character, accompanying with the improved photocurrents and the negative shift of onset potentials. The bottom W doping led to the most notable enhancement on the PEC performance for the BiVO4 electrode, which yielded the close photocurrent densities of ∼4.4 mA cm−2 at 1.23 VRHE under front and back illumination. Impressively, along with the excellent PEC performance, the cocatalyst-free photoanode exhibited a favorable stability during 25 h test applied at 1.0 VRHE. These results demonstrated that the synergy of various enhancement strategies including WO3/BiVO4 nanojunction formation, W-doping, and oxygen vacancy creation can be directly incorporated into such a nanostructure during the one-step synthesis of BiVO4 without complex post-treatment.

The WO3 nanofilms were fabricated by a reported method [35]. 1.25 g tungstate (H2WO4) and 0.5 g ploy(vinyalcohol) (PVA) in 20 mL H2O2 (30 wt%) were dissolved and stirred at 80 °C to prepare a solution for the following spin coating. The solution was coated onto the FTO substrate, followed by annealing at 400−650 °C for 2 h to form a seed layer. Then, the precursor solution was prepared by dissolving 0.625 g H2WO4 in 10 mL H2O2 (30 wt%) and 30 mL deionized (DI) water with stirring at 92 °C. The above solution was diluted with DI water to 100 mL, forming a 0.025 M H2WO4 precursor solution. A mixture solution contained 3 mL H2WO4 precursor solution (0.025 M), 2.75 mL DI water, 0.25 mL HCl (37.5 wt%), and 10 mL ethylene glycol. This solution and FTO substrate (with a WO3 seed layer) were transferred to 50 mL stainless-steel Teflon-lined autoclave for heating at 180 °C for 1−3 h. After reaction, the substrate was taken out, washed with DI water, and dried at 60 °C. Finally, the obtained sample was annealed at 500 °C in air for 1 h.

A nanoporous layer of BiVO4 was coated on the WO3/FTO substrate by the electrodeposition method [36]. Firstly, the pH of 50 mL KI solution (0.4 M) was adjusted to 1.7 by concentrated HNO3, followed by the addition of 0.97 g Bi(NO3)3·5H2O. 20 mL of 0.23 M p-benzoquinone ethanol solution was added to the above solution. A typical three-electrode cell is used for the electrodeposition to form BiOI film on WO3/FTO. The deposition of the BiOI film was carried out at -0.1 V versus Ag/AgCl for 180 s. Then, 0.15 mL of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) containing 0.2 M vanadyl acetylacetonate (VO(acac)2) was dropped on the BiOI, and heated at 450 °C for 2 h in a furnace to obtain BiVO4 photoanode. The annealed electrode was immersed in a 1 M NaOH solution for 30 min to remove the excess V2O5. Finally, the W:BiVO4 photoanode was washed with deionized water and dried in air. For comparison, the BiVO4 photoanodes were prepared on the FTO substrate.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of top W:BiVO4 and middle W:BiVO4 photoanodes
ce:section.ce:para: The top W:BiVO4 photoanode was obtained by following the same procedure as BiVO4 photoanodes, except for the addition of tungsten source (ammonium tungstate) in the DMSO solution. To prepare middle W:BiVO4, the procedure was the same with the BiVO4 photoanode, except that the ammonium tungstate was added into the precusor solution for the deposition of BiOI.

The W:BiVO4-Ov samples were obtained by activating the W:BiVO4 samples using the potentiostatically polarized technique applied at 0.8 VRHE in 1 M KBi (pH = 9.5) under AM 1.5 G (100 mA cm−2) front illumination.

The crystalline structure was identified by X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) using Rigaku RINT-2000 (Cu Kα radiation). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed using FE-SEM-Supra 55 system. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns were obtained using a JEOL-JEM-2100 F system. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) and ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) analysis were conducted on an ESCALAB 250Xi using a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source. The work function was estimated from the following equation of work function = hν - E cutoff. Here, hν = 21.2 eV (He I source), E cutoff represents the onset of the secondary-electron emission. The valence-band maxima were calculated by the equation of E V = work function + E VBM. Here, E VBM represents the difference between the Fermi energy level and the valence-band maximum obtained from the onset of valence band photoemission on the low-binding-energy edges of UPS spectra. Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) spectra of the samples were recorded on a JEOL-JES-FA200 spectrometer at low temperature (−150 °C). UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra were performed on a UV-2600i (Shimadzu) spectrometer by using barium sulfate (BaSO4) as the reference. The room temperature photoluminescence (PL) and time-resolved photoluminescence spectroscopy (TRPL) were obtained using a FLS980 spectrophotometer.

The PEC performances of the photoelectrodes were measured by a CHI 760E electrochemical workstation with a 300 W Xenon lamp (PLS-FX300HU, Beijing Perfectlight Technology Co., Ltd.) as light source. The photoanode, an Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) electrode, and a Pt foil were used as the working electrode, the reference electrode and the counter electrode, respectively. All the illuminated areas were 1 cm2 under AM 1.5 G illumination (100 mW cm−2). The Ag/AgCl can be converted to RHE scale with the Nernst equation:
(1)
E (vs. RHE) = E (vs. Ag/AgCl) + 0.0591×pH + 0.1976
where E (vs. RHE) and E (vs. Ag/AgCl) are the potentials versus RHE and the measured potentials versus Ag/AgCl reference electrode, respectively. Incident photoelectron conversion efficiency (IPCE) was obtained in 1 M KBi at a potential of 1.23 VRHE using a Xe lamp . IPCE was calculated following the equation:
(2)
I P C E ( % ) =
J × 1240
λ ×
P
L i g h t
× 100 %
here, J is the measured photocurrent density at a specific wavelength, λ is the wavelength of incident light, and PLight is the measured light power density at the wavelength. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed at 0.8 VRHE with an AC voltage amplitude of 10 mV in the frequency range from 0.1 Hz to 100,000 Hz. Mott-Schottky (MS) spectra were obtained at a frequency of 1000 Hz in dark. The donor densities were calculated by Mott-Schottky equation:
(3)

here,

is the electron charge, ε is the relative permittivity of BiVO4 ( ε = 68),

is the permittivity of vacuum,
N d
is the donor density, V is the applied bias at the electrode,
V f
is the flat band potential.

All density functional theory calculations were carried out by Vienna ab-Initio Simulation Package (VASP) [37]. Core electrons were described by pseudopotentials generated from the projector augmented wave method, [38] and valence electrons are expanded in a plane-wave basis set with an energy cutoff of 460 eV. The Perdew-Burke- Ernzerh (PBE) exchange correlation functional was used. A (2 × 2 × 1) supercell consisting of 96 atoms was constructed to study the electronic structure of bulk BiVO4. One V atom in the supercell was replaced by W atom to study the varies of electronic structures when BiVO4 was doped by W. One or two Oxygen atoms were removed to introduce Oxygen defects. The BiVO4 (121) surface was modeled by a (2 × 2) supercell consisting of 96 atoms and a vacuum of 16 Å. For the sampling of Brillouin-zone integrals, Gamma centered k-points grid of 3 × 3 × 3 and 3 × 3 × 1 were used for bulk model and slab model. During structure optimation, all energy change criterion was set to 10−4 eV, the atoms were relaxed until the force acting on each atom was less than 0.02 eV Å-1.

ce:section.ce:section-title: PEC performances of W:BiVO4 with various W doping profiles
ce:section.ce:para:
It has been known that the BiVO4 photoanode has a short diffusion length and sluggish electron transfer rate at the BiVO4/substrate interface, which needs to be illuminated from the back side to reduce this imperfection. The front-illuminated PEC performance is therefore lower than that of back illumination as illustrated in the inset of Fig. 1
a. In this context, we induced the WO3 located at the interface of BiVO4/FTO substrate to accelerate the electron transport, and meanwhile, a trace of W was doped into the bulk BiVO4 during the annealing treatment. The dispersed WO3 nanofilm was firstly prepared on the FTO substrate through a hydrothermal approach. The BiOI was then synthesized on the WO3/FTO substrate by an electrodeposition method (Fig. S1), following with the thermal treatment in a dimethyl sulfoxide solution containing Vo(acac)2 to transform BiVO4 sample. During the annealing, the W element would naturally diffuse into the BiVO4 because of the contact of two components in the embedded structure, in which the V5+ was replaced by W6+ from the back side. For comparison, we prepared the samples with various W doping profiles, - top, middle, and bottom doping. The doped samples were marked as W:BVO. Fig. 1 a-c shows the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) for the W:BVO photoanodes with various W doping profiles in 1 M KBi (pH = 9.5) under AM 1.5 G (100 mW cm−2) illumination. All the electrodes exhibit an increased photocurrent density in both front and back illumination. In view of W doping from the top surface, it still shows the higher photocurrent from back illumination than that of front illumination (Fig. 1 a), which is consistent with the pristine BiVO4 photoanode (inset of Fig. 1a). In contrast, the middle W:BVO and the bottom W:BVO photoanodes display a slightly higher front-illuminated PEC performance compared to the BiVO4 (Fig. 1 b,c). These collective data demonstrate that the W doping from the back side could accelerate the electron transfer, and the WO3 underlayer can be considered as an electron transport layer for facilitating the charge carrier and improving the front-side PEC performance.

On the other hand, as a result of the defects induced by W doping, the BiVO4 photoanodes display the photo-activation character through potentiostatic polarization measurement. Fig. 1 d shows the J-t curves of W:BVO with various W doping profiles after potentiostatic polarization applied at 0.8 VRHE under 1 sun front illumination, and the polarized samples were remarked as W:BVO-Ov. The middle W:BVO and bottom W:BVO photoanodes present the quick decay in photocurrents at the beginning of the test, and then the photocurrents gradually increase to a slope after 2−4 h, accompanying with the stable values after 6 h. The top W:BVO sample shows a slow decreased photocurrent until 30 min, along with a slow growth in photocurrent up to 6 h. The initial photocurrent decay could be attributed to the dissolution of vanadium from BiVO4. Considering the un-treated top surface for the middle and bottom W doping profile, the V dissolution rates are faster than that of top W:BVO photoanode. The W concentration in the latter is higher for the outer than the inner, resulting in the slow photo-activation happened on the top W doping profile. After that, the increased tendency in photocurrent can be referred to the formation of passivation layer as the previous study reported [14]. This phenomenon is similar to the metal corrosion protection, where an increased current density obtained means the passivated and protected film formed in the dilute chloride solution [39,40]. Besides, the WO3 film and the pristine BiVO4 on the FTO substrate have not shown any activation process in KBi electrolyte as evidenced in Figs. S2 and S3, which suggests that the photo-activation comes from the defect-control of BiVO4 photoanode.

We further compared the PEC performances of the electrodes after potentiostatic polarization, and the related LSV curves are provided in Fig. 1e. It can be observed that the bottom W:BVO-Ov presents the highest photocurrent of 4.4 mA cm−2 at 1.23 VRHE with an onset potential of 0.35 VRHE, compared with 2.94 mA cm−2 for the middle W:BVO-Ov and 2.65 mA cm−2 for the top W:BVO-Ov. The bottom W:BVO-Ov exhibits the closed photocurrent values in both front and back illumination regarding sample to sample variation (Fig. 1f). For comparison, the optimal condition for various polarized potentials and different deposition thicknesses of BiVO4 on the bottom W doping was performed as shown in Figs. S4 and S5. The pronounced improvement in PEC performance on the bottom W:BVO-Ov can be assigned to the enhanced charge separation as a result of the reduced carrier recombination and internal electric field from W gradient doping profile. The role of W doping mainly induces the shallow-level defects, and the bottom W doping would match well the gradient distribution of defects, which further increases the defect intensity on the BiVO4 film. However, the low photoresponse for the top W:BVO-Ov electrode, even lower than that of the middle W:BVO-Ov, is possibly due to the unmatched defect concentration. Further on, Fig. 1 g compares the photocurrent densities attained at 1.23 VRHE for the samples with various W doping profiles before and after photo-activation. The bottom W:BVO exhibits the higher increased ratio before and after treatment than those of the top W:BVO and the middle W:BVO electrodes. The oxygen vacancies were also formed on the top surface during the potentiostatical polarization. Therefore, combined with the high W doping concentration at the surface, the massive defects could be generated which leads to the deep-level recombination. The UV–vis absorption of W:BiVO4-Ov with various W doping profiles was investigated as illustrated in Fig. 1 h. The bottom W:BVO electrode has a high absorption in comparison to the middle W:BVO and the top W:BVO samples in the range of 300 nm–450 nm. Importantly, the long-term stability for the electrodes were examined at 1.0 VRHE under front illumination (Fig. 1i). The photocurrent of bottom W:BVO was stable for 25 h approximately, which is better than those of middle W:BVO and top W:BVO samples, and meanwhile it is one of the best stabilities for the cocatalyst-free BiVO4 samples (Tables S1 and S2). By contrast, the pristine BVO and the top W:BVO samples have a rapid decay in photocurrent. For the W doping, it could be attributed to the low charge transfer at the interface and fast charge recombination happened at the interface of BVO/electrolyte. The top W doping would bring the new surface recombination during the stability measurement. Combined with the above results, it can be concluded that upon bottom W doping and photo-activation process induced, the cocatalyst-free BiVO4 has a strong photocorrosion resistance performance.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effect of WO3 underlayer on BiVO4
ce:section.ce:para: The bottom W doping comes from the deposited WO3 films located on the interface of BiVO4/FTO substrates. Previous researches have demonstrated that the WO3 has a strong ohmic contact to the FTO substrate, therefore improving the electron transfer to the back side for hydrogen production [34]. X-ray diffraction (XRD) results confirm the formation of WO3 (JCPDS: 83−0951) (Fig. 2 c). The bottom W:BVO film exhibits the signal peaks consistent with the pristine BiVO4 (JCPDS: 83–1699), and the WO3 phase is also detected in XRD pattern. Fig. 2 a,b and d–i shows the scanning electron microscopy (SEM), cross-sectional scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) images and corresponding EDS maps on the bottom W:BVO film. The BiVO4 has a nanoporous structure with a particle size of 100−200 nm (Fig. 2a). The EDS element mapping reveals the presence of WO3 film underneath the BiVO4, and the distribution of W doping as displayed in Fig. 2 i. The high-resolution TEM image in Fig. 2 b displays the clear grain boundaries at the interfaces of SnO2/WO3 and WO3/BiVO4. Fig. S6 indicates the high crystallinity of WO3 film with a thickness of around 50 nm. Since the W:BVO film was further photo-activated by potentiostatic polarization, a thin layer around 2−10 nm is formed on the top surface compared to the relatively smooth top surface of non-treated W:BVO films (Figs. 2 j and S7). This could be ascribed to the influence of potentiostatic polarization, resulting in the surface passivation and the reduction of surface recombination [14,40].

The ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) and UV–vis spectra were employed to investigate the band edge positions of W:BVO before and after photo-activation. The WO3 film was also examined for comparison. The work functions of W:BVO and W:BVO-Ov (Fig. 2k) were deduced by subtracting the cut-off energies (E cutoff). As shown in Fig. 2 l and m, Tauc plot presents an indirect bandgap of 2.76 eV for WO3, whereas the W:BVO and W:BVO-Ov exhibit a direct bandgap of 2.46 eV and 2.44 eV, which are in line with the theoretical values [41,42]. The positions of the valence band maxima in relation to the Fermi levels were obtained from the onset of valence band photoemission on the low binding energy edges of UPS spectra (Table S3). The exact band positions for the corresponding electrodes are provided in Fig. 2 n. Both the conduction band and the valence band for the W:BVO-Ov electrode have a negative shift. The V5+ was replaced by W6+, resulting in the defects (e.g. oxygen vacancies) on the bulk BiVO4. This defected BiVO4 electrode hence can be photo-activated during potentiostatic polarization. The photo-activation process further induces the surface defects, causing the shorten band gap on W:BVO-Ov.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Surface state and oxygen vacancies for W:BVO-Ov
ce:section.ce:para:
To study the influence of photo-activation process on the W:BVO-Ov electrode, X-ray photoemission spectrometry (XPS) and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy measurements were carried out to clarify the defects during photo-potentiostatic polarization as function of time. There is no significant change for the Bi 4f and V 2p spectra from the initial time to 100 s, whereas a shift to the low binding energy (B.E.) can be seen from 1 h to 6 h (Fig. 3
a,b). Detected from O 1s spectra of Fig. 3c, the oxygen peak presenting the oxygen deficient region (Ov) becomes strong with an increasing ratio from 20.1%–29.3% (Table S4). These results manifest that the surface state changes, especially the surface oxygen vacancies produced on the top surface during the photoactivation. Additionally, a weak W 4f peak can be found with an atomic ratio of 1.5 at.% (Fig. 3 d and Table S5), which evidences that the W is definitely diffused to the top surface during the annealing treatment. Further polarization with time does not obviously change the W concentration, and still remains 1.5–1.8 at.% on the top surface of BiVO4 (Table S5). For comparison, the W 4f spectrum for the WO3 film grown on the FTO substrate can be probed as displayed in Figs. 3 e and S8, a couple of W 4f7/2 and W 4f5/2 obtained, which is clearly coincided with the literature reported [41]. Fig. 3 f shows the EPR spectroscopy for the various polarized samples. It could be assured that the W:BVO electrode before photo-activation has a g signal intensity, and this signal intensity raises from 100 s to 6 h, revealing the presence of defects on the pristine sample and the increased defects (e.g. oxygen vacancies) during photo-potentiostatic polarization.

The photoactivation process could be ascribed to the defects existing on the BiVO4 sample since the W was induced. We then measured the incident photon to electron conversion efficiency (IPCE) for the W:BVO and W:BVO-Ov photoanodes (Fig. 4 a). The IPCE value of the W:BVO-Ov photoanode reaches up to 77.4 % at 470 nm, vastly higher than that of W:BVO electrode (36.4 %). To clarify the charge separation process and interface properties, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) investigated the dynamics of carrier transport as shown in Fig. 4 b. All the electrodes exhibit two semicircles, indicating the presence of two capacitance in the system. The W:BVO and W:BVO-Ov have a much smaller diameter than the pristine BVO. The lowest diameter of the semicircle on W:BVO-Ov presents the lowest resistance after the introduction of W and oxygen vacancies (Table S6), indicating a decline in the interfacial charge transfer resistance (Rct) in the photoelectrode, [43] which is in agreement with the above PEC results. Mott-Schottky analysis also determines the charge carrier density (Nd), in which the Nd values are 1.16 × 1018 cm−3, 5.47 × 1018 cm−3, and 1.36 × 1019 cm−3 for the BVO, W:BVO, and W:BVO-Ov electrodes, respectively (Fig. 4 c and Table S7). The high charge carrier density on W:BVO-Ov is owing to the synergistic effect of oxygen vacancies and W doping. To investigate the surface oxygen vacancies and W doping for the enhanced photocurrent density, the surface separation efficiency (ηsurface) and bulk charge-separation efficiency (ηabs×sep) were performed in KBi solution that contains Na2SO3 as a hole scavenger (Figs. 4 d,e and S9). As seen from Fig. 4 d, the surface charge separation efficiency of W:BVO-Ov is much higher than that of pristine BVO and W:BVO. This result confirms the fast charge carrier transport and the reduction of surface recombination for the W:BVO-Ov, again demonstrating that the influence of passivation layer as detected from TEM observation (Fig. 2j). The bulk charge-separation efficiencies for the W:BVO and W:BVO-Ov also improve compared to the BVO sample, and both of them present the resembled values (Fig. 4e). The change in surface separation efficiency is obvious than that of bulk charge separation efficiency on W:BVO-Ov, which means that the interface structure between electrode/electrolyte is the main essential factor that improves its PEC performance for water oxidation. The photoactivation appears to reduce the interface recombination much more than the bulk recombination; the bulk recombination is well suppressed under the introduction of W doping and modification of WO3 films on the substrate. The effect of W induces the photo-activation, and further impairs the surface recombination. Moreover, photocurrent transient assessment of the charge recombination at the electrode/electrolyte interface provides an additional evidence for the above results. As the irradiation was suddenly turned on, the photocurrent decay on BVO or W:BVO photoanode is rapid (Fig. 4f), which is mainly attributed to the recombination of holes trapped at the surface states with electrons in the conduction band. The photocurrent decay of W:BVO-Ov photoanode is sluggish, suggesting the fact that the photoelectrochemical treatment could ameliorate the interface recombination [44].

We next turn to the time-resolved photoluminescence (TRPL) spectrum to probe the charge carrier process as shown in Fig. 4 g. Fitting the decay curve using a double exponential decay model, the W:BVO-Ov has a longer carrier lifetime (τ1 = 3.21 ns, τ2 = 46.97 ns) than those of the pristine BVO and W:BVO (Table S8). Moreover, the room temperature photoluminescence (PL) spectrum of the sample as shown in Fig. 4 h was further verified the above results. As expected, the W:BVO-Ov electrode displays the lowest PL intensity, which could be attributed to the combined effect of oxygen vacancy and W doping facilitating the charge transfer to improve charge separation efficiency.

To further understand the advantages of W:BVO-Ov, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed. Density of states (DOS) were firstly calculated to explore the change of electronic structures as illustrated in Fig. 5
a-d. For the stoichiometric BiVO4, the calculated bandgap is around 2.03 eV (Fig. 5a) which is close to the theoretical value (2.4 eV). When the W atom was introduced into the BiVO4, the shape of total DOS does not vary evidently except that the fermi level moves to the previous conduction band edge (Fig. 5b). This shift of fermi level suggests that the W atom provides the electrons to BiVO4, which would improve the conductivity of BiVO4. As the oxygen vacancies were further introduced, the inter-band states can be found in the DOS spectra of Fig. 5 c and d. These inter-band states lead to the increase of optical absorption and carrier density as evident in Fig. 4. Further on, to investigate the improved oxygen evolution reaction (OER) activity with the W doping and oxygen vacancies, the OER pathway on the BVO and W:BVO-Ov was discussed based on the 4e-mechanism proposed by Norskov [37,38]. According to the experimental results, the (121) surface was selected. The optimized structure of the intermediates in the free-energy landscape are shown in Fig. 5 e-f. When the V ions on the surface were selected as the active sites on the BiVO4, the rate-determining step is the formation of *O from *OH with ΔG = 2.47 eV (Fig. 5e), which agrees well with the previously reported value. As the W was doped into the material with oxygen vacancies, the W ions were selected as the active site, and the rate-determining step changes to be the formation of *OOH from *O with ΔG = 2.03 eV (Fig. 5f). Therefore, the W doping and oxygen vacancies remarkably reduce the Gibbs free energy for OER, facilitating the OER kinetics. The calculated results provide an additional evidence that the W:BVO-Ov has a better OER performance, which is consistent with the above experimental results.

In summary, we designed a new strategy to prepare WO3 modified BiVO4 photoanode with defect control. The WO3 layer underneath the BiVO4 facilitated the electron transfer from BiVO4 to WO3, but more importantly, was used as a diffusion source for W doping which brought oxygen vacancies on the bulk material. On the other hand, different W doping profiles - top, middle, and bottom doping, were induced, and all electrodes exhibit a photo-activation character, accompanying with the improved photocurrents and the negative shift of onset potentials. The bottom W doping led to the most notable enhancement in charge separation efficiency on the BiVO4 electrode, which yielded the close photocurrent densities of ∼4.4 mA cm−2 at 1.23 VRHE under front and back illumination. Impressively, the cocatalyst-free W:BiVO4 photoanode with oxygen vacancies exhibited a long-term photocorrosion resistance performance. These results demonstrated that the synergy of various enhancement strategies including WO3/BiVO4 nanojunction formation, W-doping, and oxygen vacancy creation can be directly incorporated into such a nanostructure during the one-step synthesis of BiVO4 without complex post-treatment. This work provides a completely novel WO3/BiVO4 heterojunction to photo-activate the bulk material and suppress the interface recombination, which has a potential application for energy solar conversion.

L.W. supervised the work and wrote the original manuscript. S.L. synthesized the materials and performed the photoelectrochemical analyses. Z.W. conducted/wrote the DFT calculations. R.-T.G., R.Z., X.L., T.N., X.Z., and Y.S. assisted the data analysis and discussion. Z.W., Y.S., and L.W. revised the manuscript. All authors contributed to the discussion and declared no conflict of interest.
The authors declare that they have no financial and personal relationships with other people or organizations that can inappropriately influence our work.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: The work was financially supported by the National Natural Science Foundations of China (51802320, 21872074, 21965024), the 111 project (D20033), the Central Government Guiding Special Funds for the Development of Local Science and Technology (2020ZY0012), the Inner Mongolia funding for Distinguished Young Scholars (2020JQ01), start-up funding from Inner Mongolia University (21300-5195102), and the opening project of Key Laboratory of Materials Processing and Mold from Zhengzhou University. The DFT calculation was carried out at LvLiang Cloud Computing Center of China, and it was performed on TianHe-2.
